30.description: 'Biggest ever' investigation into police actions promised over Hillsborough  via @itvnews

31.description:
'Biggest ever' investigation into police actions promised over Hillsborough  via @itvnews The biggest ever inquiry into police actions in the UK is to be launched after a damning report on the Hillsborough disaster.

Police watchdog the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) said a large number of serving and former officers will be investigated over what happened on the day of the tragedy in 1989, and during the alleged cover-up afterwards.

Director of Public Prosecutions Keir Starmer also said he will look at whether any individual or corporate body should be charged over the football stadium disaster, which left 96 people dead.

Mr Starmer said: “Having read and considered the report published by the Hillsborough Independent Panel on 12 September 2012 and liaised with the Home Office and Independent Police Complaints Commission, I have concluded that the Crown Prosecution Service should consider all the material now available in relation to the tragic events on 15 April 1989, including the material made available by the Independent Panel.

195.description: Hillsborough: Largest inquiry launched into police  Tragedy of its time & chilling warning for ages

196.description: Hillsborough: Largest inquiry launched into police  Tragedy of its time & chilling warning for ages  The police watchdog for England and Wales has said it is launching the largest-ever inquiry into police actions following the publication last month of a damning report into the response to and aftermath of the Hillsborough disaster.

197.description: Hillsborough: Largest inquiry launched into police  Tragedy of its time & chilling warning for ages  ‘B******s – no one would have been killed’ – the stridently, chillingly complacent riposte came from the then-chairman of Sheffield Wednesday, yet could have tripped from the lips of many more. Police, Pressmen, council officials, emergency services – and even, maybe, if more understandably blithely, fans who would and should never have expected to head to the football, let alone with Wembley promise in the air, never to head home again.
